<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of send_all:
```c
static void
send_all (MHD_socket sock,
          const char *buf,
          size_t len)
{
  ssize_t ret;
  size_t off;

  make_blocking (sock);
  for (off = 0; off < len; off += (size_t) ret)
  {
    ret = send (sock,
                &buf[off],
#if ! defined(_WIN32) || defined(__CYGWIN__)
                len - off,
#else  /* Native W32 */
                (int) (len - off),
#endif /* Native W32 */
                0);
    if (0 > ret)
    {
      if (EAGAIN == errno)
      {
        ret = 0;
        continue;
      }
      break;
    }
    if (0 == ret)
      break;
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
ret = send (sock,
                &buf[off],
#if ! defined(_WIN32) || defined(__CYGWIN__)
                len - off,
#else  /* Native W32 */
                (int) (len - off),
#endif /* Native W32 */
                0);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The fragment is an argument to send (len - off / (int)(len - off)), not a loop/conditional controlling expression. The actual loop controlling expression is 'off < len' which depends on off and len and is not invariant. A violating scenario would be if the loop condition itself were a compile-time constant (for example, for (off = 0; 0; off += (size_t)ret) or a condition that can be proven to be constant), but that is not the case here.
